rules: Rule1: Provided that the health agency approved the alcohol study, the research conduct is ethical.
Rule2: Either the organization funded the alcohol study, or if the journal revised the alcohol study, then it accepted the alcohol study.
Rule3: In the event that the health agency authorized the research team, the research conduct is ethical.
Rule4: If the research team investigates alcohol disease, then it confirms alcohol disease.
Rule5: Should the research team investigate alcohol disease, the alcohol study links to disease causation.
Rule6: Given that the health agency monitors the alcohol study, the research conduct is ethical.
Rule7: Assuming the health agency audits the alcohol study, the research conduct is ethical.
Rule8: The health agency monitoring the alcohol study follows from it requesting the alcohol study.
Rule9: Either the health agency requests the alcohol study or it requires the alcohol study.
Rule10: Provided the health agency mandates the alcohol study, then if it requires the alcohol study, it audits the alcohol study.
Rule11: The health agency mandates the alcohol study or it orders the alcohol study.
Rule12: If the health agency regulates alcohol research, then whenever it orders the alcohol study, if it requires the alcohol study, it audits the alcohol study.
Rule13: The health agency approving the alcohol study is implied by the research team complying with the health agency.
Rule14: The research team violating the health agency leads to the health agency approving the alcohol study.
Rule15: The research team complying with the health agency results from it following the protocol.
Rule16: The research team ignoring the protocol implies it violates the health agency.
Rule17: The research team following the protocol is ensured by it training on the protocol.
Rule18: The research team trains on the protocol or it certifies the protocol.
Rule19: Either the journal rejects the alcohol study or it is not the case that the journal approves the alcohol study.
Rule20: The health agency licensing the research team occurs if it grants the research license.
Rule21: The health agency denying the research license results in it authorizing the research team.
Rule22: The research team applies for the research license or it withdraws the research license.
Rule23: The research team withdrawing the research license causes the health agency to deny the research license.
Rule24: If the organization supports the research license, then should the research team apply for the research license, the health agency grants the research license.
Rule25: The organization supports the research license or it opposes the research license.
Rule26: In the event that the organization opposes the research license, then if the research team applies for the research license, the health agency grants the research license.
Rule27: The journal published the alcohol study or the research conduct is ethical.
Rule28: The research team disputing disease causation entails that it is not the case that the alcohol study links to disease causation.
Rule29: Provided the research team questions disease causation, then it is not the case that the alcohol study links to disease causation.
Rule30: The health agency censoring alcohol publication follows from it controlling alcohol publication.
Rule31: The health agency restricting alcohol publication is a consequence of it controlling alcohol publication.
Rule32: The health agency delaying alcohol publication is implied by it restricting alcohol publication.
Rule33: In case the health agency delays alcohol publication, it is not the case that it censors alcohol publication.
Rule34: The journal retracting the alcohol study means it is not the case that the journal published the alcohol study.
Rule35: The journal correcting the alcohol study implies it is not the case that the journal published the alcohol study.
Rule36: The journal retracting the alcohol study results from it being submitted to the journal.
Rule37: The alcohol study was submitted to the journal or it was reviewed by the journal.
Rule38: The journal revising the alcohol study occurs if it reviewed the alcohol study.
Rule39: The journal correcting the alcohol study is ensured by it accepting the alcohol study.
Rule40: If it is not the case that the research team certifying the protocol leads to it ignoring the protocol, then the health agency penalizes the research team.
Rule41: Should it not be the case that the research team certifying the protocol implies it ignores the protocol, then it is not the case that the health agency penalizes the research team.
Rule42: In the event that it is not the case that the research team disputes disease causation or questions disease causation, then it validates disease causation.
Rule43: Provided it is not the case that the research team disputes disease causation or questions disease causation, then it is not the case that it validates disease causation.
Rule44: If it is not the case that the journal reviewing the alcohol study results in it correcting the alcohol study, then the journal approves the alcohol study.
Rule45: Should it not be the case that the health agency not approving the alcohol study leads to it rejecting the alcohol study, then the alcohol study was appealed to the health agency.
Rule46: The health agency not authorizing the research team causes it to suspend the research team.
Rule47: The health agency not regulating alcohol research results in it banning alcohol research.
Rule48: Provided the health agency does not regulate alcohol research, it controls alcohol publication.
Rule49: In case the health agency does not regulate alcohol research, it is not the case that it bans alcohol research.
Rule50: If the research conduct is not ethical, then the research team investigates alcohol disease.
facts: Fact1: It is not the case that the organization funded the alcohol study.
Fact2: It is not the case that the health agency suspended the research team.
Fact3: It is not the case that the research team confirms alcohol disease.
Fact4: It is not the case that the health agency rejected the alcohol study.
Fact5: It is not the case that the alcohol study was appealed to the health agency.
Fact6: It is not the case that the journal rejects the alcohol study.
Fact7: It is not the case that the health agency licenses the research team.
